Graphical abstract The pH effects play a critical role in electro-catalysis, yet their influence on the structural evolution of electrocatalysts during the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) remains underexplored. In this study, we combined in-situ Raman and UV–Vis spectroscopy with density functional theory (DFT) calculations to track the structural evolution of electrodeposited amorphous cobalt (oxy)hydroxide under different pH conditions. Our findings reveal distinct responses of the synthesized catalyst to varying electrolyte pH levels. The formation of relatively ordered β-CoOOH structure from amorphous cobalt (oxy)hydroxide under alkaline conditions may serve as the active phase, while the less active amorphous cobalt (oxy)hydroxide remained stable under neutral conditions. This study emphasizes the pivotal role of electrolyte pH in driving surface reconstruction of metal oxides, even in the absence of applied electrode potential. Keywords Cobalt (oxy)hydroxide Oxygen evolution reaction Active phase Surface reconstruction pH effects Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Water electrolysis emerges as a promising method for sustainable hydrogen production, a key green energy carrier, especially when utilizing electricity from renewable sources like solar, wind, or hydropower [1]. While hydrogen evolution at the cathode is relatively facile, the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER) poses challenges due to its sluggish kinetics. To address this, various non-precious metal oxide catalysts, particularly Fe, Co and Ni-based ones [2–7], have been developed to enhance activity and stability, providing a cost-effective alternative to noble Ir and Ru-based catalysts. On the electrolyte side, particularly concerning electrolyte pH, recent recognition has underscored its significant role in electrocatalysis through modulating the proton donor (H3O+ or H2O) [8,9], adsorbate dipole-field interaction [10], solution phase reactions with OH− [11], and interfacial water structure [12]. In-depth mechanistic studies have further uncovered that electrolyte pH can influence the coupling and decoupling of the electron transfer and proton transfer, as well as dictate the reaction pathways (heterogeneous or homogeneous) [13,14]. It is therefore vital to understand the interaction between solid metal oxide catalyst and electrolyte pH dictating the electrocatalytic properties. Recently, researchers have shown that electrolyte pH can influence the surface reconstruction of transition metal-based electrocatalysts and the formation of active sites during OER. A cobalt-based perovskite catalyst, Ba0.5Sr0.5Co0.8Fe0.2O3-δ, exhibits an increase in the oxidation state of Co and the formation of an active (oxy)hydroxide layer under highly alkaline conditions (pH 13) when anodic potentials are applied [15]. This behaviour is not pronounced under near-neutral conditions. Similarly, the formation of “active oxygen” species in nickel based catalyst is strongly dependent on the pH of the electrolyte, with a deprotonation process being favoured in strongly alkaline media [16]. In nickel-based crystalline catalysts, the rate of surface degradation depends on the pH, whereas the amorphous Ni (oxy)hydroxide catalyst is more stable and unaffected by pH changes [17]. Despite these findings, a molecular understanding of the role of electrolyte pH on surface reconstruction and its impact on OER activity is still lacking. Among the developed non-precious metal oxides, cobalt (oxy)hydroxide represents as a typical model catalyst and are widely suggested as the in-situ formed active species in perovskite oxides [18], sulphides [19] and phosphides [20]. However, the exact identification of active species at the molecular level still remains elusive, ranging from Co3+ species [6,21,22] to Co4+ species [2,23], possibly owing to the complicated surface reconstruction process during OER. A. T. Bell group suggested that Co4+ species, formed by the oxidation of cobalt oxide facilitated by the gold substrate, contribute to OER activity. This conclusion is primarily based on in-situ Raman spectroscopy, although direct evidence of the presence of Co4+ species is still lacking [2]. Meanwhile a Co4+ species was identified under OER potential from Co 2p spectra by ambient pressure XPS [23]. Hu group proposed that the oxidation of Co4+ species from Co4+–O–Co4+ to Co4+–O•–Co4+ is actually the key step to initiate oxygen release in cobalt (oxy)hydroxide conducted under alkaline conditions [24,25]. In contrast to these proposals, Co3+ species at the edge site have been considered as the active species based on the results of correlative operando scanning probe and X-ray microscopy techniques [22]. Combined experimental and theoretical tools revealed a charge reorganization within the Co3+δO6 unit, resulting in an oxyl radical instead of Co4+ formation during OER, which is critical for OER [6]. In addition to the valence state, the high spin state of Co3+ was identified to contribute in regulating electron transfer ability and facilitating OER [26]. It is worthwhile to note that previous experiments were typically conducted in highly alkaline media with cobalt (oxy)hydroxide. Considering the potential effect of electrolyte pH on the surface reconstruction of transition metal-based oxides, this factor may play an important role in the formation of active species, which needs to be explored further. The structural evolution of cobalt oxides in electrolytes of varying pH has been extensively investigated in recent studies [27–29]. Hausmann et al. established that a cobalt selenite pre-catalyst follows distinct transformation pathways depending on pH and electrochemical potential [30]. Under simultaneous high pH (>13) and anodic polarization, it forms a bulk-active disordered structure with expanded interlayer spacing, whereas sequential alkaline pretreatment followed by polarization produces a crystalline (oxy)hydroxide with restricted accessibility, confining catalytic activity to the surface region. Under acidic conditions, online mass spectroscopic studies reveal that Co3O4 dissolution is most severe upon initial contact with the electrolyte under anodic polarization, compared to later stages [31]. This phenomenon may arise from rapid surface oxidation, leading to transient dissolution due to restructuring. Further operando studies suggest that pH critically governs OER activity by modulating cobalt’s redox dynamics: alkaline conditions facilitate efficient low-potential Co oxidation, whereas neutral or acidic media impede redox kinetics, increasing overpotential [32]. These results underscore the critical role of Co3+/4+ redox behaviour tuning in optimizing OER activity. Additionally, in-situ UV–Vis spectroscopic studies have provided evidence for the formation of Co4+ species, with their generation being dependent on OH– concentration [33]. The OER activity demonstrates a potential-dependent relationship with both pH and Co4+ content: at 1.54 V vs. RHE, the activity shows no dependence on either electrolyte pH or Co4+ concentration, while at 1.59 V vs. RHE, a clear correlation emerges with both parameters. This phenomenon can be explained by the fact that elevated OH– concentrations require abundant Co4+ sites to sustain high current densities, while at lower potentials, the diminished need for Co4+ species results in comparable OER activity regardless of pH conditions. While prior studies have examined pH and potential-dependent structural evolution in cobalt oxides, the pure effects of neutral to alkaline medium on phase reconstruction remain insufficiently characterized. Hence, we employed a combined in-situ spectroscopic methodology to explore the pH effects on the structural evolution of cobalt (oxy)hydroxide pre-catalyst. Our findings directly confirm the previously overlooked importance of electrolyte pH on cobalt oxide catalysts, particularly under alkaline conditions compared to neutral conditions. Under purely alkaline conditions, we observed the partial transformation of the amorphous cobalt (oxy)hydroxide pre-catalyst into a relatively ordered β-CoOOH phase, where active species likely formed in situ under anodic conditions. In contrast, under neutral conditions, the amorphous cobalt (oxy)hydroxide pre-catalyst remained stable, and the high-valent Co species generated during the anodic scan on this amorphous phase might exhibit less OER activity. This discovery sheds light on the complex dynamics of active structure formation and the influence of the electrolyte environment on the substrate, offering valuable insights for the development of more efficient OER catalysts. 2 Experimental and theoretical methods Material synthesis. Thin films of CoOxHy were fabricated on indium tin oxide (ITO) glass substrates obtained from Advanced Election Technology Co., Ltd. (Yingkou, China) via anodic electrodeposition at a constant current density of 55.6 μA cm−2. Before deposition, the ITO glass was cut into 2.0 × 0.8 cm2 sections and thoroughly cleaned by sonication in a 1:1 ethanol and acetone mixture for approximately 30 min. The deposition bath for cobalt (oxy)hydroxide contained 0.01 M Co(NO3)2·6H2O (Aladdin, 99.99 % metal basis) and 0.1 M NaCH3CO2 (Aladdin, ≥99 %), with NaCH3CO2 serving as the supporting electrolyte. The final electrolyte pH was approximately 7.85. A single-chamber three-electrode cell configuration was used, with ITO as the working electrode, Ag/AgCl as the reference electrode, and a Pt wire as the counter electrode. The deposition process lasted 20 min, resulting in thin film samples with good optical transparency and favorable electrical conductivity. Refer to Supporting Information, Fig. S1 for an illustration of the synthesis process. Characterization. The morphology and elemental mapping of the samples were characterized using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitach FlexSEM 1000 II). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images, high-angle annular dark-field scanning TEM (HAADF-STEM) images, and energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) data were recorded with an FEI Talos F200s G2 operating at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. For identical location-TEM (IL-TEM) investigations, a certain amount of catalyst was dispersed in alcohol. The resulting suspension was then drop-cast onto a 200-mesh gold finder TEM grid coated with a 30 nm thick holey carbon film. Chemical composition and valence information were obtained via X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) using Thermo Scientific equipment. XPS data were calibrated by aligning the peak of the adventitious carbon C 1 s to 284.8 eV. Phase characterization of the film samples was performed using a grazing-incidence X-ray diffractometer (GI-XRD, Rigaku Smartlab, Japan) with Cu Kα radiation (wavelength λ = 1.5418 Å). The grazing incidence angle was α = 5°, with a scanning range of 10° to 80°, a scanning rate of 5°/min, and a step size of 0.02°. Raman spectroscopic analysis was conducted using a Renishaw inVia confocal Raman microscope equipped with a 532 nm excitation laser (Renishaw, RL532C50) with a nominal output power of 50 mW. The spectrometer is coupled to a Leica DM LM microscope, enabling microscopic analysis with a 50 × N PLAN (0.75NA) objective. The excitation power was maintained at 0.5 % of the laser output power, and scans with an exposure time of 2 min each (for ex-situ measurements) were performed. Potential laser-induced damage to the sample was carefully assessed by incrementally increasing power levels; no discernible damage was detected. Prior to the Raman analysis, the spectrometer was calibrated using a silicon wafer (520.5 cm−1). Electrochemical measurement. All electrochemical experiments were conducted using a standard three-electrode system with either an Autolab Metrohm potentiostat or a CHI660e potentiostat. A Hg/HgO (or Ag/AgCl) reference electrode and a carbon rod served as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. Electrochemical experiments were performed in O2-saturated alkaline or neutral electrolytes. Specifically, 1.0 M and 0.1 M KOH solutions (pH ∼ 14 and ∼ 13, respectively; measured values: 13.97 and 12.95) were prepared by dissolving KOH pellets (Aladdin, 99.99 % metal basis) in Milli-Q water. Additionally, a neutral electrolyte (pH ∼ 7; measured value: 7.04) was prepared using a mixture of K2HPO4 and KH2PO4 (both Aladdin, 99.99 % metal basis) to yield a 0.1 M phosphate buffer (K1.6H1.4PO4). The reported pH values were obtained using a calibrated pH meter (model FiveEasy Plus, Mettler Toledo) at room temperature. All potentials were referenced to a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) unless otherwise stated, calculated using the equations: (1) E RHE = E 0 + 0.0592 × p H + E H g / H g O ( 0.097 V ) (2) E RHE = E 0 + 0.0592 × p H + E A g / A g C l ( 0.197 V ) Cyclic voltammetry (CV) was conducted with a scan rate of 100 mV s−1. Linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed over a range of 0.9 to 1.72 V, using a scan rate of 5 mV s−1. Regarding Tafel plots, there are significant concerns about using potentiodynamic polarization curves (e.g., LSV with slow scan rates) as discussed in the literature [34], since this approach can yield misleading results regardless of scan rate. For this reason, we adopted the steady-state measurements (chronoamperometry, CA) strongly recommended in the referenced study, rather than dynamic techniques, for reliable Tafel slope determination. For LSV measurements, we applied 95 % iR compensation during data acquisition. For CA tests, we performed 100 % iR compensation during post-processing to enable precise Tafel analysis. Regarding CV measurements, we did not apply iR compensation during fast scans to maintain consistency with previously reported data [35]. Operando ultraviolet–visible (UV–Vis) spectroscopy. The operando UV–Vis measurements were conducted using an Autolab spectrophotometer equipped with a three-electrode system within a custom-made electrochemical cell (refer to Supporting Information, Fig. S2a). A Hg/HgO (or Ag/AgCl) electrode and a carbon rod were used as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. The excitation source covered a wavelength range from 200 nm to 1100 nm. The measuring time for each spectrum was 8 s. The ITO glass coated with the catalyst was integrated into the electrochemical cell to ensure proper irradiation of the sample. At the open circuit potential (OCP), a spectrum was recorded and used as the blank spectrum. Subsequently, the potential was raised stepwise from OCP to anodic potentials. Through repeated measurements, we consistently obtained OCP values ranging from 0.97 to 1.28 V vs. RHE slightly depending on the electrolyte pH. Operando spectroscopic measurements were then conducted at each constant potential simultaneously with the recording of current information (activity). The in-situ Raman measurements were conducted using a three-electrode system within a customized electrochemical cell (refer to Supporting Information, Fig. S2b). A Hg/HgO (or Ag/AgCl) electrode and a Pt wire served as the reference and counter electrodes, respectively. The CoOxHy film catalysts were deposited onto a carbon substrate for analysis. During the multi-step potential protocol, Raman spectra were recorded at various potentials, ranging from OCP to 1.50 V (alkaline conditions) or 1.70 V (neutral conditions), before returning to OCP. The actual applied potential was subsequently increased to 1.70 V under alkaline conditions; however, gas bubble formation led to blurring in the Raman measurements. Consequently, Raman measurements were halted at 1.50 V. Each potential step was maintained for 25 min, and an exposure time of 5 min was used to obtain in-situ spectra after the current stabilized. Models and Computational Details. The structure models of CoOOH-A P 6 3 / m m c and CoOOH-B R 3 ¯ M were obtained from the Materials Project website (https://legacy.materialsproject.org/) and the conventional standard unit cells are shown in Fig. S3. For accurate phonon dispersion calculations, the cell of CoOOH-A was expanded to 2 × 2 × 2, and the cell of CoOOH-B to 2 × 2 × 1. DFT calculations were performed by using the Vienna Ab initio Simulation Package (VASP) code [36], with the projected augmented wave (PAW) pseudopotentials and the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) exchange–correlation functional under the Generalized Gradient Approximation (GGA) [37]. Ionic relaxations were performed by using conjugate-gradient algorithm. To correct for the van der Waals interaction, The DFT-D3 method with the Becke-Johnson damping function was applied [38]. The cutoff energy was set to 520 eV, and Gaussian smearing width was set to 0.1 eV. The finite difference approach with ± 0.015 Å displacements was employed to calculate the mass-weighted Hessian matrix required for vibrational frequency calculations in the harmonic approximation. In all of the calculations, a 5 × 5 × 3 Monkhorst-Pack k-point mesh was employed. Initial structures were fully relaxed until the residual forces were smaller than 10-5 eV/Å and the total energy was converged to within 10-8 eV. We utilized a modified script based on the Python script by Fornari and Stauffer [39] and the density functional perturbation theory (DFPT) method to selectively calculate the Raman activity for vibrations in the range of 300–800 cm−1. In the Raman spectra plot, a Gaussian broadening (sigma = 10) was applied to obtain the calculated Raman spectra. 3 Results and discussion The CoOxHy film catalyst was prepared using an electro-deposition method as described in previous literature [24]. The deposited film exhibited a brown colour following anodic electrodeposition at a constant current density (Fig. 1 a and Supporting Information, Fig. S1c). SEM showed the film morphology comprised flat plates separated by cracks that formed upon drying [40] (Fig. 1b). In addition, XPS detected Co and O elements, as well as In, Sn, and Si elements originating from the ITO substrate, and some elements (C, N, K) that may have come from the electrolyte and environment (Supporting Information, Fig. S4). GIXRD analysis showed the CoOxHy film to be X-ray amorphous, evidenced by a large amorphous hump centred at ∼ 25° that completely obscured the underlying ITO diffraction pattern (Fig. 1c) [41]. The ITO substrate itself exhibited characteristic In2O3 patterns, with the dominant peak at ∼ 30° showing tin-doping-dependent intensity variations [42]. Nanoscale elemental mapping via TEM-EDX (Fig. 1d and Supporting Information, Fig. S5a) demonstrated homogeneous Co and O distribution throughout the film. High-resolution TEM (HRTEM) imaging revealed predominantly amorphous characteristics and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) patterns displayed diffuse rings, indicative of absence of long-range crystallinity (Fig. 1d). Collectively, these analyses confirm the material's poor crystallinity and near-amorphous nature. CV measurements were conducted on the film catalysts to track the redox transitions of Co species at various pH levels. As depicted in Fig. 2 a, two reversible redox peaks (denoted as A2/C2 and A3/C3) were observed at pH 13 and pH 14. They are commonly assigned to the redox transition of Co2+/Co3+ and Co3+/Co4+ [24,43–46]. However, such assignment may neglect the oxidative charge accumulated in the oxygen (Co3+–O1−, not Co4+=O) [6]. Alternatively, they can be assigned to Co2+/Co2.54+ and Co2.54+/Co3+ or Co2+/Co3+ and Co3+/Co(3+δ)+ transitions [22,35]. The A2 peak shifted toward higher potential at pH 13 compared to pH 14, demonstrating pH-dependent behaviour consistent with prior reports [32]. At pH 7, the two oxidation and reduction peaks merged into one broad peak each, respectively, as evidenced by the anodic peak position around 1.55 V (close to the A3 peak) and the cathodic peak position around 1.13 V (close to the C2 peak). Due to a lack of accurate oxidation state analysis, we refrain from assigning these redox peaks in the present study. Nevertheless, the variation in peak positions at different pH levels suggests that the initial structures may differ depending on the pH. The slight changing peak positions during scan cycles indicate structural modifications during electrochemical treatment (Supporting Information, Fig. S6) [47]. Another partially irreversible redox peak found around 1.05 V (denoted as A1) is likely due to the oxidation of surface uncoordinated Co2+ species from H2O adsorption [46]. The influence of electrolyte pH on OER activity was investigated using LSV measurements. As shown in Fig. 2b, the OER activity generally increased with higher pH levels. Notably, at low overpotentials, the activity in alkaline conditions was nearly independent of pH within the margin of experimental error (see Supporting Information, Fig. S7), consistent with previous reports [33]. Although the CoOxHy catalyst remained active at pH 7 compared to the bare ITO electrode, its performance was significantly lower than in alkaline conditions. The Tafel plots (Fig. 2c) exhibited a similar pH-dependent trend, with the Tafel slope decreasing as pH increased. A particularly notable increase in Tafel slope values occurred when transitioning from alkaline to neutral conditions, implying a distinct difference in reaction mechanisms between the two pH regimes. This pH-dependent behaviour in both OER activity and Tafel slopes may be attributed to changes in the oxidation state of cobalt [32,48]. The film catalysts were then examined before and after electrochemical treatments using XPS to assess the variation in oxidation states. As recently highlighted by Lu [49], the nominal Co3+ and Co4+ states in cobalt oxides exhibit nearly identical main peak positions, with oxidation state differences primarily reflected in satellite peak features rather than main peak shifts. For this reason, our analysis focused on the satellite peak evolution to track cobalt oxidation state changes instead of main peak shifts. As shown in Fig. 2d, the as-synthesized CoOxHy exhibited a dominance of Co3+, as evidenced by the satellite peak found around 790 eV [50–52]. After CV cycles and LSV test, a slight shift of Co 2p 3/2 peak toward higher binding energy (before: 779.58 eV; pH 14: 780.08 eV; pH 13: 780.08 eV) under alkaline electrolyte indicates partial reduction of Co after the reaction [24,51,53], while the dominance of Co3+ remained due to the unchanged satellite peak. However, under neutral conditions, Co2+ became dominant in the sample after electrochemical treatment, as evidenced by the extended width of the Co 2p3/2 peak and the satellite peak around 786 eV [50–52]. Additional analysis of the O 1 s XPS spectrum delineated three main peaks: one at 529.6 eV associated with lattice oxygen (O2−), another at 530.9 eV assigned to O atoms in surface hydroxyl groups (OH−), and a third at 532.3 eV linked to adsorbed water molecules (Supporting Information, Fig. S8) [21,24,51,53]. The most significant difference observed among these samples was the notable reduction of surface hydroxyl groups and an obvious increase in adsorbed water molecules following electrochemical treatment under neutral conditions (Supporting Information, Table S1). These results suggest that the electrolyte pH, along with the applied potential, can have a significant influence on the distribution of Co2+/Co3+ species and surface oxygen species. Moreover, morphological analysis by SEM showed aggregation of small particles instead of a flat plate surface at the three different pH levels (Supporting Information, Fig. S9), indicative of significant structural reconstruction processes. To correlate the valence state variation of Co with OER activity, operando UV–Vis spectroscopy was adopted under neutral and alkaline conditions. The operando UV–Vis spectra are presented in the Fig. 3 . Notably, the onset of OER current emerged around 1.5 V at pH 13, aligning with our LSV data. At pH 7, discernible OER current manifested only above 1.6 V. Examining the UV–Vis spectra, at pH 7, a band around 400 nm at 1.3 V was attributed to the Co2+ to Co3+ transition [54], due to the charge transfer transition between p orbitals of O2– and the eg orbitals of Co3+. Beyond 1.3 V, a broad band centred around 550 nm was associated with the transition from Co3+ to Co4+ or other high-valent Co species, corroborating our CV results and prior reports [25,48]. The absorption band around 550 nm reached almost maximum at 1.6 V which was in line with the onset of OER current. Similarly, at pH 13, the Co2+ to Co3+ transition started to appear around 1.1 V, corresponding to the A1 peak in the CV curve (Fig. 2a). And the absorption band around 550 nm associated with Co4+ or other high-valent Co species got maximum at 1.6 V. In short, Fig. 3 provides qualitative evidence that the intensity of the 550 nm band is comparable under both pH 7 and pH 13 conditions, despite the latter condition showing superior catalytic activity. A quantitative analysis presented in Fig. S10 of the Supporting Information further reveals the absence of a linear correlation between the 550 nm band intensity and catalytic activity under both pH 7 and pH 13 conditions, suggesting that this spectral feature corresponds to a spectator species rather than an active one, consistent with previous reports [25]. According to an operando UV–Vis study by Lee et al., [25] an additional band at 450 nm, associated with a high-valent Co species identified as Co4+–O•–Co4+ and formed by the oxidation of Co4+–O–Co4+ during the OER on cobalt (oxy)hydroxides, was observed at pH 7 but not at pH 14 in the present study. One possible explanation is that the high reactivity of the Co4+–O•–Co4+ species under alkaline conditions results in its low surface coverage. Alternatively, the enhanced OER activity in alkaline media may not originate from the species associated with the 450 nm and 550 nm absorption features. Additionally, the true active species in alkaline media might remain undetected, possibly due to the limited spectral resolution of UV–Vis spectroscopy and/or the weak visible-light absorption of octahedrally coordinated Co4+ [55]. To further investigate the influence of pH on the active structure evolution during the anodic scan, in situ Raman spectroscopy was performed across a pH range from neutral to alkaline conditions (see the experimental apparatus in Supporting information, Fig. S2b). The structure of the as-synthesized CoOxHy closely resembled that observed under neutral conditions (see Supporting Information, Fig. S11). At pH 7, a broad Raman feature at ∼ 605 cm−1 with a shoulder peak at ∼ 523 cm−1 was commonly assigned to amorphous cobalt (oxy)hydroxide [2,24] (see Fig. 4 a and Fig. S11b), which was consistent with the SAED and GIXRD results. The main peak and shoulder peak were ascribed to the stretching (A1g) and bending modes (Eg) of Co-O, respectively. Other forms of cobalt oxides, such as CoO, Co(OH)2, and Co3O4, were ruled out by comparing these features with standard reference compounds (Supporting Information, Fig. S12). A shift toward a lower wavenumber of the main peak was observed when the applied potential changed from 1.6 to 1.7 V, which was attributed in previous reports to the formation of high-valent cobalt oxide species (e.g. CoOx) [2]. This may coincide with the formation of Co4+–O•–Co4+ or Co4+–O–Co4+ species as observed by our operando UV–Vis spectroscopy (Fig. 3a). When the potential was returned to the OCP, the shift reverted to the original feature, indicating a quasi-reversible process. Notably, under alkaline electrolyte (pH 13 and 14), even at the OCP, the Raman spectrum of the CoOxHy sample exhibited a sharp peak at 499 cm−1 and a broad peak around 605 cm−1, in contrast to the neutral condition (Fig. 4b and 4c). The Raman feature at 499 cm−1 was assigned to β-CoOOH according to previous studies [56–58]. As will be discussed later, the formation of β-CoOOH is purely from chemical reaction, not electrochemical effects. It is noteworthy that two patterns of Raman spectra from cobalt (oxy)hydroxide have often been reported [2,24,56,58–60], though the subtle differences between them may be overlooked. One pattern is similar to the Raman feature obtained under neutral conditions without the sharp peak around 499 cm−1. The other pattern exhibits a sharp peak around 499 cm−1 with a broad peak around 605 cm−1, similar to what we observed under alkaline conditions. It has also been found that increasing the deposition temperature can induce the transformation of Raman features from the former to the latter, although without detailed discussion regarding structural implications [41]. As shown in Fig. 4b and 4c, with the increase in applied potential, the peak intensity at 499 cm−1 decreased relative to the broad peak, and the width of the peak at 499 cm−1 broadened as well. A peak shift of the broad peak toward lower wavenumbers from OCP to oxidizing potentials was observed at both pH 13 and pH 14. Note that the potential range up to 1.50 V used for Raman spectra collection under alkaline conditions is scientifically meaningful, as it aligns with the onset of the OER current, as shown in Fig. 2c. Consistent with the case at pH 7, the peak intensity attenuation and peak shift were also partially reversible when the potential was returned to OCP. To further resolve the variation of peak profiles along with potential, we performed deconvolution analysis (Fig. 4d and 4e, see details in Supporting Information, Figs. S13-14). The Raman spectra obtained under alkaline conditions were considered to consist of both amorphous CoOxHy and relatively ordered β-CoOOH, the latter identified by its characteristic sharp peak. The Raman features (peak positions and area ratio of the two peaks) from amorphous CoOxHy were deemed to be stable below 1.7 V, as evidenced in Fig. 4a. For detailed deconvolution results identifying the two phases (amorphous CoOxHy and β-CoOOH) present under alkaline conditions, please refer to the Supporting Information, Figs. S13 and S14. In addition, we identified a small shoulder peak (∼634 cm−1) on the broad peak (∼605 cm−1), which was assigned to residual Co2+ species, as it disappeared above 1.2 V under pH 13 and pH 14, consistent with the redox profile of the A1 peak in Fig. 2a. Therefore, in contrast to the neutral case, we attribute the observed broad peak shift under alkaline conditions to oxidative depletion of residual Co2+ species, resulting in an apparent peak displacement. Further quantification of the relative intensity (I499/I605) and the full width at half maximum (FWHM) of the peak at 499 cm−1 showed that this attenuation and broadening initiated at 1.4 V for pH 14 and 1.5 V for pH 13 (Fig. 4f), suggesting structural disordering and its potential relationship with the OER [56]. Consequently, on the amorphous CoOxHy substrate, immersion in an alkaline medium produced a relatively ordered β-CoOOH structure. As the applied potential increased anodically, this in-situ formed relatively ordered β-CoOOH structure became disordered, initiating at different potentials depending on the electrolyte pH conditions. While the formation of γ-CoOOH during anodic scans was reported in previous studies [58,61], which differs primarily in its stacking sequence and interlayer distance from β-CoOOH, our experimental results show no evidence of γ-CoOOH formation. It is supported by the absence of its characteristic Raman signatures at 463 and 572 cm−1 [58,62]. The reason can be ascribed to the kinetically favoured formation pathway of β-CoOOH relative to γ-CoOOH [58]. Another increasing Raman signal with applied potential was observed at 1064 cm−1 (Supporting Information, Fig. S15). This Raman feature was attributed to adsorbed superoxide species (Co-OO–), which are known to occur in a similar range between 900 and 1050 cm−1 from Co and Ni based oxides [16,24,63]. The possibility that this Raman feature from the amorphous CoOxHy or β-CoOOH phase itself, which was suggested from previous study [51], was excluded since the trend of increasing intensity with anodic scan was not consistent with that from two phases. To confirm the origin of the sharp peak at 499 cm−1, chemical immersion experiments in alkaline solution (pH 14) characterized by Raman spectroscopy were conducted. We measured six sampling points on the sample before and after chemical immersion for various time, and the results are shown in Fig. 5 a–c and Supporting Information, Fig. S16. The essentially identical Raman features sampled from six points revealed that the structure of sample was homogeneous in terms of Raman spectroscopy, regardless of whether chemical immersion was performed. More importantly, the alkaline solution induced the formation of the sharp peak at 499 cm−1, as evidenced by the increasing relative intensity with longer immersion times. Here we demonstrate that pure chemical immersion actually leads to the formation of β-CoOOH. This result indicates the formation is due to the chemical adsorption of OH− on the coordination unsaturated site of CoOxHy, as reported in previous literature [51,56,59,60,64]. Due to the sharp Raman feature suggesting its relatively ordered nature, GIXRD measurement was performed. The results indicate that the sample treated with alkaline solution predominantly retained its X-ray amorphous character (Fig. 5d). IL-TEM showed that the morphology remained intact after chemical immersion (Fig. 5e-f), and the elemental distribution of Co and O was even without any aggregation or leaching (Fig. 5g and Supporting Information, Fig. S5b). It should be noted that during the IL-TEM measurements, the carbon film was inadvertently flipped between measurements. This change in orientation may account for both the apparent increase in image transparency after chemical immersion and the corresponding attenuation of the EDX signals, as shown in Supporting Information, Fig. S5b. The corresponding SAED result further confirm the absence of long-range order of the sample after chemical immersion (Fig. 5h). We subsequently performed DFT calculations to determine that the Raman peak at 499 cm−1 originating from β-CoOOH. Two β-CoOOH crystalline structures, differing in the arrangement of CoO6 layers connected by hydrogen atoms, were analysed (Fig. 6 a). In addition to calculating vibrational frequencies, we also computed the Raman intensity, which are essential for interpreting experimental Raman spectra, particularly when distinguishing between closely spaced phonon modes. Interestingly, both structures exhibited a single strong peak around 470 cm−1, which was close to the observed value of 499 cm−1 (Fig. 4b and Fig. 6b). This peak, consisting of degenerate phonon modes, was attributed to Co-O bending modes, as shown in the insets of Fig. 6b and Supporting Information, Fig. S3. The ∼ 30 cm−1 deviation between the DFT-predicted Raman peak (∼470 cm−1) and the experimentally observed peak at 499 cm−1 can be ascribed to the well-known systematic underestimation of vibrational frequencies by commonly used GGA functionals, such as the Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional [65]. This red-shift is primarily due to the tendency of such functionals to underestimate bond strengths and associated force constants [66,67]. Overall, the simulated Raman spectra show excellent agreement with the characteristic vibrational fingerprint of β-CoOOH, particularly through the presence of a single strong Raman band in the relevant region. Although our calculations utilized the crystalline structure rather than the experimental amorphous configuration, these results provide indirect evidence that distinct β-CoOOH configurations, even in the absence of long-range order, can maintain nearly identical vibrational frequencies when the essential hydrogen connected CoO6 layer structure remains intact. The influence of pure electrolyte pH was further investigated through macroscopic contact angle measurements and gas bubble adhesion force analysis. The CoOxHy film catalyst exhibited similar initial contact angles (71.0°–73.9°) in both neutral and alkaline electrolytes, suggesting comparable surface energy states during initial wetting (Fig. 7 a–b). However, in alkaline media (pH 14), rapid hydroxylation of the surface (confirmed by in situ Raman spectroscopy) enhanced hydrophilicity, reducing the contact angle to 20.6° within 10 min. In contrast, neutral electrolytes did not induce significant surface hydroxylation, resulting in a more hydrophobic surface. Bubble adhesion behaviour, governed by the wetting state at the under-electrolyte surface [68], diverged markedly over time due to pH-dependent surface restructuring. The alkaline electrolyte exhibited an ultralow bubble adhesion force (1.668 μN, Fig. 7d), nearly 40 times lower than in neutral conditions (61.705 μN, Fig. 7c). This stark contrast in wetting behaviour directly correlates with OER performance: the alkaline condition’s minimal bubble adhesion (<2 μN) mitigates mass transport limitations, while neutral conditions suffer from bubble accumulation and active site blockage. These results clearly provide that pH alone, independent of the electrode potential effects noted in prior work [69], critically controls surface wetting states as well and thereby directly determines catalytic efficiency. The potential effects of electrolyte cations were examined to decouple their effects from those arising solely from pH variations. The consistent use of potassium ions across both neutral and alkaline conditions enabled us to exclude their potential role in inducing structural modifications. Regarding potential Fe contamination in the electrolyte and its effects on activity [25,70–72], several control experiments were performed. First, to minimize Fe impurities, we used high-purity KOH pellets (99.99 %) and estimated that 1.0 M KOH solutions without further purification contain Fe at levels significantly below ppm. Second, we performed electrochemical experiments, including CA and CV, to evaluate OER activity and redox behaviour with and without added Fe ions. As shown in Supporting Information, Fig. S17a, the addition of Fe had no noticeable effect at 0.14 ppm, but it modestly enhanced activity (∼24 %) with up to 2.1 ppm Fe at pH 14. A prolonged equilibration time of 1 h was employed to accommodate potential slow Fe incorporation into the CoOxHy structure. Notably, the Fe addition caused an immediate activity response, suggesting that the observed activity enhancement likely stems from adsorbed Fe species rather than gradual incorporation processes. While under neutral conditions, the activity remained largely unchanged, though a slight decay over time was observed (Supporting Information, Fig. S17b). Figs. S17c-d in Supporting Information showed that the addition of Fe had no effect on the redox features of Co, consistent with prior study [35]. These results indicate that Fe impurities (at sub-ppm levels) in the current system exert only a minimal influence on the activity. Third, we performed additional Raman characterization with Fe-adding samples to verify that the newly formed Raman feature at 499 cm−1 was not caused by Fe contamination. Raman spectra of CoOxHy catalysts exposed to 0.14 ppm Fe under neutral conditions showed no detectable feature at ∼ 499 cm−1 (Supporting Information, Fig. S18), confirming that the observed Raman signal arises from pH effects rather than Fe impurities. While our findings support prior observations regarding iron's influence above certain concentration thresholds, this work controls for iron interference and primarily focuses on pH-driven cobalt structural transformations. Based on the above results, we propose that under alkaline conditions, amorphous CoOxHy transforms into a relatively ordered but still noncrystalline β-CoOOH through OH− insertion into cobalt octahedra, forming a hydroxylated cobalt (oxy)hydroxide (Scheme 1 ). This β-CoOOH layer enhances hydrophilicity and, as evidenced by XPS data, mitigates catalyst reduction during electrochemical treatments. CV and UV–Vis spectra revealed that the A1/A2 and A3 peaks correlate with absorbance bands at ∼ 400 nm and ∼ 550 nm, respectively. We attribute the 550 nm band to Co4+–O–Co4+ species and the 450 nm band to Co4+–O•–Co4+ intermediate formed on the as-synthesized amorphous CoOxHy. These features are not directly involved in the OER. In contrast, the in-situ-formed β-CoOOH, identified by its characteristic Raman peak at 499 cm−1, exhibited potential-dependent and quasi-reversible behaviour at the OER onset, suggesting that the active species responsible for OER are formed on the catalytically active β-CoOOH phase, rather than the high-valent Co species generated on amorphous CoOxHy. As the β-CoOOH phase becomes increasingly disordered under anodic conditions, catalytically active species emerge. While the precise structure of this active species requires further investigation, the appearance of a characteristic Raman band at 1064 cm−1 provides clear evidence for the stabilization of a CoOO– intermediate during this process. It is important to note that while conventional Raman spectroscopy has limited surface sensitivity, our study focuses on the formation of a bulk β-CoOOH active phase that is revealed by Raman spectroscopy. Further we used the Raman spectroscopy to prove that it develops upon electrolyte contact (pH sensitive), and exhibits potential-dependent evolution correlating with OER activity (potential sensitive). These findings gain additional support from complementary surface-sensitive techniques including XPS, and contact angle measurements as well as UV–Vis spectroscopy. 4 Conclusion In summary, we have synthesized an amorphous CoOxHy film catalyst via electro-deposition and explored its structural evolution and electrochemical performance across different pH conditions. Under alkaline conditions, the catalyst surface transformed into the relatively ordered β-CoOOH layer, likely driven by OH− insertion on the coordination-unsaturated Co sites. This layer, confirmed by a sharp Raman peak at 499 cm−1 and supported by DFT calculations, exhibited decreasing intensity and broadening as the anodic potential increased, coinciding with the onset of the OER current. In contrast, under neutral conditions, the amorphous CoOxHy structure remained stable but demonstrated significantly lower OER activity. The formation of high-valent cobalt species from the oxidation of amorphous CoOxHy, as corroborated by CV and operando UV–Vis spectroscopy, exhibited lower activity compared to β-CoOOH. This study emphasizes the critical influence of electrolyte pH on the structural evolution of cobalt oxide pre-catalyst, which correlates with their OER performance, revealing the often-overlooked pure electrolyte pH effects in previous research. This leads us to propose that electrocatalyst design should be approached as “pre catalyst” design, requiring simultaneous consideration of the initial material properties, purely chemical effects, and their interplay with electrochemical factors. coredata.dc:description: The pH effects play a critical role in electro-catalysis, yet their influence on the structural evolution of electrocatalysts during the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) remains underexplored. In this study, we combined in-situ Raman and UV–Vis spectroscopy with density functional theory (DFT) calculations to track the structural evolution of electrodeposited amorphous cobalt (oxy)hydroxide under different pH conditions. Our findings reveal distinct responses of the synthesized catalyst to varying electrolyte pH levels. The formation of relatively ordered β-CoOOH structure from amorphous cobalt (oxy)hydroxide under alkaline conditions may serve as the active phase, while the less active amorphous cobalt (oxy)hydroxide remained stable under neutral conditions. This study emphasizes the pivotal role of electrolyte pH in driving surface reconstruction of metal oxides, even in the absence of applied electrode potential.
